lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent: Sometimes Python is unable to understand our code. This results in something called a SyntaxError.

lessons.title: Misspelt keywords
lessons.interactiveContent:
Syntax errors are usually due to typos, such as misspelled keywords. Like iff at the beginning of this code block.

Make sure to pick >, followed by 10.

lessons.title: Incorrect indentation
lessons.interactiveContent:
Incorrect or missing indentation will result in an IndentationError, which is a specific type of SyntaxError.

Make sure to pick print.

lessons.title: Misplaced keywords
lessons.interactiveContent: Putting a keyword in the wrong place will also cause a SyntaxError.

lessons.title: Missing symbols
lessons.interactiveContent:
Leaving out symbols, such as colons and brackets, will also cause a SyntaxError.

Make sure to pick if, followed by cost.

lessons.title: Incomplete statements
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we try to run incomplete statements like in the following code we'll also receive a SyntaxError.

Make sure to pick >, followed by :.

lessons.title: Error detail
lessons.interactiveContent:
Sometimes Python can add more detail to the error, like in the following code where a string is mistakenly used as a variable name.

Make sure to pick "name", followed by =.

lessons.title: Error location
lessons.interactiveContent: The ^ symbol, known as a caret, indicates in the console where the error has been found in the code.

lessons.title: Question: Misspelt keywords
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which statement will result in a SyntaxError?

wile age < 11:age = 16

wile age < 11:.

lessons.title: Question: Incorrect indentation
lessons.interactiveContent:
What error will appear if there are extra blank spaces in the code?

Indentation ErrorSyntax Error

Indentation Error.

lessons.title: Question: Misplaced keywords
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which statement will result in a SyntaxError?

else print("hello")print("help")

else print("hello").

lessons.title: Question: Missing symbols
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which statement will result in a SyntaxError?

total = 5 + 3 8total = 5 + 3 + 8

total = 5 + 3 8.

lessons.title: Question: Error detail
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which error will the following code produce?

SyntaxError: unexpected EOF while parsing SyntaxError: can't assign to literal

SyntaxError: unexpected EOF while parsing .

lessons.title: Question: Error location
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which character in an error message can help us work out where the error in the code is?

A hashtag #A caret ^

A caret ^.

lessons.title: Example: Misspelt keywords
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add an if statement that does not result in a SyntaxError.

Make sure to pick if, followed by print.

lessons.title: Example: Incorrect indentation
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the print() statement and avoid an IndentationError.

Make sure to type print.

lessons.title: Example: Misplaced keywords
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a statement which does not result in an error.

Make sure to pick if, followed by or.

lessons.title: Example: Missing symbols
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete this statement without producing a SyntaxError.

Make sure to pick =, followed by *.

lessons.title: Example: Incomplete statements
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the code so that value is printed.

Make sure to pick 50, followed by 20, and finally print.

lessons.title: Example: Error detail
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete this code so that an error is produced in the console.

Make sure to pick "david", followed by name.

lessons.title: Example: Error location
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete this code to produce a SyntaxError.

Make sure to pick if, followed by users:.

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent: Sometimes Python understands our code, but cannot execute it.

lessons.title: Exceptions
lessons.interactiveContent:
Python will raise an exception when it cannot perform an operation. It will show one for the given code since size isn't defined.

Make sure to pick =.

lessons.title: Traceback
lessons.interactiveContent: The text shown in the console when an exception is raised is called the traceback. It helps us debug our code, which means finding errors.

lessons.title: Exception types
lessons.interactiveContent: ZeroDivisionError, NameError and TypeError are examples of different types of exceptions.

lessons.title: Exception variety
lessons.interactiveContent:
We'll encounter many types of exceptions when creating programs, relating to things such as indexing, file references, variables.

Make sure to pick print, followed by (, and finally ).

lessons.title: Undefined variables
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we try to use a variable that doesn't exist, we'll get an error.

Make sure to pick =, followed by results.

lessons.title: Unknown attributes
lessons.interactiveContent:
Objects may not have attributes or methods that we think they have, like using a mean function that does not exist for lists.

Make sure to pick mean, followed by (, and finally ).

lessons.title: Not found but no error
lessons.interactiveContent: Some methods don't produce errors and are able to handle issues themselves. In the following code count() returns zero when nothing exists.

lessons.title: Question: Exception types
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which type of exception will this code raise?

NameErrorTypeError

Make sure to pick NameError.

lessons.title: Question: Undefined variables
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following will result in a NameError?

Referencing a variable that doesn't existUsing a string which is very long as a variable name

Referencing a variable that doesn't exist.

lessons.title: Question: Not found but no error
lessons.interactiveContent:
Will this code raise an exception?

No, as using in on the list where the value isn't present does not cause an errorYes, using in in this context produces an error

No, as using in on the list where the value isn't present does not cause an error.

lessons.title: Example: Exception types
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a statement which will raise a ZeroDivisionError.

Make sure to pick average, followed by /, and finally 0.

lessons.title: Example: Undefined variables
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a statement which will raise a NameError.

Make sure to pick members, followed by append, and finally "Kevin".

lessons.title: Example: Not found but no error
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add a statement which prints False, without raising an exception.

Make sure to pick print followed by "Paris" and then in, [, ].

lessons.title: Reading the traceback
lessons.interactiveContent: The traceback is best read from bottom to top, to understand what went wrong with our code.

lessons.title: Module not found
lessons.interactiveContent:
If Python cannot find a module, a ModuleNotFoundError exception will be raised.

Make sure to pick import.

lessons.title: Index out of range
lessons.interactiveContent:
If an index is out of range, an IndexError exception will be raised.

Make sure to pick [, followed by ].

lessons.title: When syntax errors occur
lessons.interactiveContent: Syntax errors are returned before Python attempts to run the code.

lessons.title: When exceptions occur
lessons.interactiveContent: This NameError exception is raised only after the SyntaxError later in the code had been fixed.

lessons.title: Debugging
lessons.interactiveContent: Error messages help us debug our code when it's not behaving the way we expect it to behave.

lessons.title: Logical errors
lessons.interactiveContent:
A logic error occurs when there is no error or exception, but our code does not work correctly. In this code, a parenthesis is missing.

Make sure to pick print, followed by average_age.

lessons.title: Question: Reading the traceback
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will be the last line in the traceback produced by this code?

NameError: name 'count' is not definedNameError: name 'space' is not defined

NameError: name 'count' is not defined.

lessons.title: Question: Module not found
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following will result in a ModuleNotFound error?

When Python is unable to locate a module of the given name to importWhen Python cannot find the Module package

When Python is unable to locate a module of the given name to import.

lessons.title: Question: Index out of range
lessons.interactiveContent:
Will the following code result in an IndexError?

No - a KeyError will be raisedYes - an IndexError will be raised

No - a KeyError will be raised.

lessons.title: Question: When syntax errors occur
lessons.interactiveContent:
Will the print() function be executed in the following code?

No - a SyntaxError will be raisedYes - because print() is before the incorrect syntax

No - a SyntaxError will be raised.

lessons.title: Question: When exceptions occur
lessons.interactiveContent:
Will the following code raise an exception?

No - because the else statement will not be executedYes - Python will check even code which isn't executed for exceptions

No - because the else statement will not be executed.

lessons.title: Question: Debugging
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will the error message tell us about what's wrong with this code?

Python doesn't support adding integers and strings togetherThe sum() function cannot be found

Python doesn't support adding integers and strings together.

lessons.title: Example: Reading the traceback
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a statement which will result in a traceback which includes unexpected EOF (End Of File) in the message.

Make sure to pick temperature, followed by >, and finally :.

lessons.title: Example: Module not found
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a statement which will import the math module.

Make sure to type math.

lessons.title: Example: Index out of range
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a statement which will result in an IndexError.

Make sure to pick reviews, followed by 6.

lessons.title: Example: When syntax errors occur
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a statement that will produce a SyntaxError.

Make sure to pick age, followed by iff, and finally >.

lessons.title: Example: When exceptions occur
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a statement which raises NameError: name 'time' is not defined.

Make sure to pick time.

lessons.title: Example: Debugging
lessons.interactiveContent:
Write code which will print how many animals are in the list, avoiding the error NameError: name 'count' is not defined.

Make sure to pick print, followed by len, and finally animals.

lessons.title: Example: Logical errors
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a statement which correctly calculates the average value of the numbers in the list.

Make sure to pick sum, followed by /, and finally len.
